If the attempt fails, the backoff timer is increased exponentially up to backoff.max. After a successful connection, the backoff timer is reset. The default is 1s.

backoff.max.description: The maximum number of seconds to wait before attempting to connect to Logstash after a network error. The default is 60s.

index.description: Optional index name. The default index name is set to filebeat in all lowercase.

proxy_use_local_resolver.description: Resolve names locally when using a proxy server. Defaults to false.

max_retries.description: The number of times to retry publishing an event after a publishing failure. After the specified number of retries, the events are typically dropped. Some Beats, such as Filebeat and Winlogbeat, ignore the max_retries setting and retry until all events are published.  Set max_retries to a value less than 0 to retry until all events are published. The default is 3.

bulk_max_size.description: The maximum number of events to bulk in a single Logstash request. The default is 2048.

timeout.description: The number of seconds to wait for responses from the Logstash server before timing out. The default is 30s.

enabled.description: Boolean flag to enable or disable the output module.

hosts.description: The list of Kafka broker addresses from which to fetch the cluster metadata. The cluster metadata contain the actual Kafka brokers events are published to.

topic.description: The Kafka topic used for produced events. The setting can be a format string using any event field. To set the topic from document type use `%{[type]}`.

key.description: The Kafka event key setting. Use format string to create a unique event key. By default no event key will be generated.

partition.hash.description: The Kafka event partitioning strategy. Default hashing strategy is `hash` using the `output.kafka.key` setting or randomly distributes events if `output.kafka.key` is not configured.

reachable_only.description: If enabled, events will only be published to partitions with reachable leaders. Default is false.

hash.description: Configure alternative event field names used to compute the hash value. If empty `output.kafka.key` setting will be used. Default value is empty list.

username.description: Authentication details. Password is required if username is set.

sasl.mechanism.description: SASL authentication mechanism used. Can be one of PLAIN, SCRAM-SHA-256 or SCRAM-SHA-512. Defaults to PLAIN when `username` and `password` are configured.

version.description: Kafka version Filebeat is assumed to run against. Defaults to the "1.0.0".

escape_html.description: Configure escaping HTML symbols in strings.

metadata.description: Metadata update configuration. Metadata contains leader information used to decide which broker to use when publishing.

retry.max.description: Max metadata request retry attempts when cluster is in middle of leader election. Defaults to 3 retries.

retry.backoff.description: Wait time between retries during leader elections. Default is 250ms.

refresh_frequency.description: Refresh metadata interval. Defaults to every 10 minutes.

full.description: Strategy for fetching the topics metadata from the broker. Default is false.

max_retries.description: The number of times to retry publishing an event after a publishing failure. After the specified number of retries, events are typically dropped. Some Beats, such as Filebeat, ignore the max_retries setting and retry until all events are published.  Set max_retries to a value less than 0 to retry until all events are published. The default is 3.

backoff.init.description: The number of seconds to wait before trying to republish to Kafka after a network error. After waiting backoff.init seconds, the Beat tries to republish. If the attempt fails, the backoff timer is increased exponentially up to backoff.max. After a successful publish, the backoff timer is reset. The default is 1s.

backoff.max.description: The maximum number of seconds to wait before attempting to republish to Kafka after a network error. The default is 60s.

bulk_max_size.description: The maximum number of events to bulk in a single Kafka request. The default is 2048.

bulk_flush_frequency.description: Duration to wait before sending bulk Kafka request. 0 is no delay. The default is 0.

timeout.description: The number of seconds to wait for responses from the Kafka brokers before timing out. The default is 30s.

broker_timeout.description: The maximum duration a broker will wait for number of required ACKs. The default is 10s.

channel_buffer_size.description: The number of messages buffered for each Kafka broker. The default is 256.

keep_alive.description: The keep-alive period for an active network connection. If 0s, keep-alives are disabled. The default is 0 seconds.

compression.description: Sets the output compression codec. Must be one of none, snappy and gzip. The default is gzip.

compression_level.description: Set the compression level. Currently only gzip provides a compression level between 0 and 9. The default value is chosen by the compression algorithm.

max_message_bytes.description: The maximum permitted size of JSON-encoded messages. Bigger messages will be dropped. The default value is 1000000 (bytes). This value should be equal to or less than the broker's message.max.bytes.

required_acks.description: The ACK reliability level required from broker. 0=no response, 1=wait for local commit, -1=wait for all replicas to commit. The default is 1.  Note: If set to 0, no ACKs are returned by Kafka. Messages might be lost silently on error.

client_id.description: The configurable ClientID used for logging, debugging, and auditing purposes.  The default is "beats".

enabled.description: Boolean flag to enable or disable the output module.

escape_html.description: Configure escaping HTML symbols in strings.

hosts.description: The list of Redis servers to connect to. If load-balancing is enabled, the events are distributed to the servers in the list. If one server becomes unreachable, the events are distributed to the reachable servers only. The hosts setting supports redis and rediss urls with custom password like redis://:password@localhost:6379.

key.description: The name of the Redis list or channel the events are published to. The default is filebeat.

password.description: The password to authenticate to Redis with. The default is no authentication.

db.description: The Redis database number where the events are published. The default is 0.

datatype.description: The Redis data type to use for publishing events. If the data type is list, the Redis RPUSH command is used. If the data type is channel, the Redis PUBLISH command is used. The default value is list.

worker.description: The number of workers to use for each host configured to publish events to Redis. Use this setting along with the loadbalance option. For example, if you have 2 hosts and 3 workers, in total 6 workers are started (3 for each host).

loadbalance.description: If set to true and multiple hosts or workers are configured, the output plugin load balances published events onto all Redis hosts. If set to false, the output plugin sends all events to only one host (determined at random) and will switch to another host if the currently selected one becomes unreachable. The default value is true.

timeout.description: The Redis connection timeout in seconds. The default is 5 seconds.

max_retries.description: The number of times to retry publishing an event after a publishing failure. After the specified number of retries, the events are typically dropped. Some Beats, such as Filebeat, ignore the max_retries setting and retry until all events are published. Set max_retries to a value less than 0 to retry until all events are published. The default is 3.

backoff.init.description: The number of seconds to wait before trying to reconnect to Redis after a network error. After waiting backoff.init seconds, the Beat tries to reconnect. If the attempt fails, the backoff timer is increased exponentially up to backoff.max. After a successful connection, the backoff timer is reset. The default is 1s.

backoff.max.description: The maximum number of seconds to wait before attempting to connect to Redis after a network error. The default is 60s.

bulk_max_size.description: The maximum number of events to bulk in a single Redis request or pipeline. The default is 2048.

proxy_url.description: The URL of the SOCKS5 proxy to use when connecting to the Redis servers. The value must be a URL with a scheme of socks5://.

proxy_use_local_resolver.description: This option determines whether Redis hostnames are resolved locally when using a proxy. The default value is false, which means that name resolution occurs on the proxy server.

enabled.description: Boolean flag to enable or disable the output module.

escape_html.description: Configure escaping HTML symbols in strings.

path.description: Path to the directory where to save the generated files. The option is mandatory.

filename.description: Name of the generated files. The default is `filebeat` and it generates files: `filebeat-{datetime}.ndjson`, `filebeat-{datetime}-1.ndjson`, etc.

rotate_every_kb.description: Maximum size in kilobytes of each file. When this size is reached, and on every Filebeat restart, the files are rotated. The default value is 10240 kB.

number_of_files.description: Maximum number of files under path. When this number of files is reached, the oldest file is deleted and the rest are shifted from last to first. The default is 7 files.

permissions.description: Permissions to use for file creation. The default is 0600.

rotate_on_startup.description: Configure automatic file rotation on every startup. The default is true.

enabled.description: Boolean flag to enable or disable the output module.

escape_html.description: Configure escaping HTML symbols in strings.

home.description: The home path for the Filebeat installation. This is the default base path for all other path settings and for miscellaneous files that come with the distribution (for example, the sample dashboards). If not set by a CLI flag or in the configuration file, the default for the home path is the location of the binary.

config.description: The configuration path for the Filebeat installation. This is the default base path for configuration files, including the main YAML configuration file and the Elasticsearch template file. If not set by a CLI flag or in the configuration file, the default for the configuration path is the home path.

data.description: The data path for the Filebeat installation. This is the default base path for all the files in which Filebeat needs to store its data. If not set by a CLI flag or in the configuration file, the default for the data path is a data subdirectory inside the home path.

logs.description: The logs path for a Filebeat installation. This is the default location for the Beat's log files. If not set by a CLI flag or in the configuration file, the default for the logs path is a logs subdirectory inside the home path.

keystore.path.description: Location of the Keystore containing the keys and their sensitive values.

enabled.description: These settings control loading the sample dashboards to the Kibana index. Loading the dashboards are disabled by default and can be enabled either by setting the options here or by using the `-setup` CLI flag or the `setup` command.

directory.description: The directory from where to read the dashboards. The default is the `kibana` folder in the home path.

url.description: The URL from where to download the dashboard archive. It is used instead of the directory if it has a value.

file.description: The file archive (zip file) from where to read the dashboards. It is used instead of the directory when it has a value.

beat.description: In case the archive contains the dashboards from multiple Beats, this lets you select which one to load. You can load all the dashboards in the archive by setting this to the empty string.

kibana_index.description: The name of the Kibana index to use for setting the configuration. Default is ".kibana"

index.description: The Elasticsearch index name. This overwrites the index name defined in the dashboards and index pattern. Example: testbeat-*

always_kibana.description: Always use the Kibana API for loading the dashboards instead of autodetecting how to install the dashboards by first querying Elasticsearch.

retry.enabled.description: If true and Kibana is not reachable at the time when dashboards are loaded, it will retry to reconnect to Kibana instead of exiting with an error.

retry.interval.description: Duration interval between Kibana connection retries.

retry.maximum.description: Maximum number of retries before exiting with an error, 0 for unlimited retrying.

enabled.description: A template is used to set the mapping in Elasticsearch By default template loading is enabled and the template is loaded. These settings can be adjusted to load your own template or overwrite existing ones. Set to false to disable template loading.

name.description: Template name. By default the template name is "filebeat-%{[agent.version]}" The template name and pattern has to be set in case the Elasticsearch index pattern is modified.

pattern.description: Template pattern. By default the template pattern is "filebeat-%{[agent.version]}" to apply to the default index settings. The template name and pattern has to be set in case the Elasticsearch index pattern is modified.

fields.description: Path to fields.yml file to generate the template

append_fields.description: A list of fields to be added to the template and Kibana index pattern. Also specify setup.template.overwrite: true to overwrite the existing template.

json.enabled.description: Enable JSON template loading. If this is enabled, the fields.yml is ignored.

json.path.description: Path to the JSON template file

json.name.description: Name under which the template is stored in Elasticsearch

json.data_stream.description: Set this option if the JSON template is a data stream.

overwrite.description: Overwrite existing template Do not enable this option for more than one instance of filebeat as it might overload your Elasticsearch with too many update requests.

index.description: A dictionary of settings to place into the settings.index dictionary of the Elasticsearch template. For more details, please check https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/mapping.html

_source.description: A dictionary of settings for the _source field. For more details, please check https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/mapping-source-field.html

enabled.description: Configure index lifecycle management (ILM) to manage the backing indices of your data streams. Enable ILM support. Valid values are true, or false.

policy_name.description: Set the lifecycle policy name. The default policy name is 'beatname'.

policy_file.description: The path to a JSON file that contains a lifecycle policy configuration. Used to load your own lifecycle policy.

check_exists.description: Disable the check for an existing lifecycle policy. The default is true. If you set this option to false, lifecycle policy will not be installed, even if setup.ilm.overwrite is set to true.

overwrite.description: Overwrite the lifecycle policy at startup. The default is false.

setup.kibana.description: Starting with Beats version 6.0.0, the dashboards are loaded via the Kibana API. This requires a Kibana endpoint configuration.

host.description: Kibana Host Scheme and port can be left out and will be set to the default (http and 5601) In case you specify and additional path, the scheme is required: http://localhost:5601/path IPv6 addresses should always be defined as: https://[2001:db8::1]:5601

protocol.description: Optional protocol and basic auth credentials.

headers.description: Custom HTTP headers to add to each request

ssl.description: X-My-Header: Contents of the header Use SSL settings for HTTPS.

level.description: There are four options for the log output: file, stderr, syslog, eventlog The file output is the default. Sets log level. The default log level is info. Available log levels are: error, warning, info, debug

selectors.description: Enable debug output for selected components. To enable all selectors use ["*"] Other available selectors are "beat", "publisher", "service" Multiple selectors can be chained.

to_stderr.description: Send all logging output to stderr. The default is false.

to_syslog.description: Send all logging output to syslog. The default is false.

to_eventlog.description: Send all logging output to Windows Event Logs. The default is false.

metrics.enabled.description: If enabled, Filebeat periodically logs its internal metrics that have changed in the last period. For each metric that changed, the delta from the value at the beginning of the period is logged. Also, the total values for all non-zero internal metrics are logged on shutdown. The default is true.

metrics.period.description: The period after which to log the internal metrics. The default is 30s.

metrics.namespaces.description: A list of metrics namespaces to report in the logs. Defaults to [stats]. `stats` contains general Beat metrics. `dataset` may be present in some Beats and contains module or input metrics.

to_files.description: Logging to rotating files. Set logging.to_files to false to disable logging to files.

path.description: Configure the path where the logs are written. The default is the logs directory under the home path (the binary location).

name.description: The name of the files where the logs are written to.

rotateeverybytes.description: Configure log file size limit. If the limit is reached, log file will be automatically rotated.

keepfiles.description: Number of rotated log files to keep. The oldest files will be deleted first.

permissions.description: The permissions mask to apply when rotating log files. The default value is 0600. Must be a valid Unix-style file permissions mask expressed in octal notation.

interval.description: Enable log file rotation on time intervals in addition to the size-based rotation. Intervals must be at least 1s. Values of 1m, 1h, 24h, 7*24h, 30*24h, and 365*24h are boundary-aligned with minutes, hours, days, weeks, months, and years as reported by the local system clock. All other intervals are calculated from the Unix epoch. Defaults to disabled.

rotateonstartup.description: Rotate existing logs on startup rather than appending them to the existing file. Defaults to true.

enabled.description: Filebeat can export internal metrics to a central Elasticsearch monitoring cluster.  This requires xpack monitoring to be enabled in Elasticsearch.  The reporting is disabled by default. Set to true to enable the monitoring reporter.

cluster_uuid.description: Sets the UUID of the Elasticsearch cluster under which monitoring data for this Filebeat instance will appear in the Stack Monitoring UI. If output.elasticsearch is enabled, the UUID is derived from the Elasticsearch cluster referenced by output.elasticsearch.

elasticsearch.description: Uncomment to send the metrics to Elasticsearch. Most settings from the Elasticsearch output are accepted here as well. Note that the settings should point to your Elasticsearch *monitoring* cluster. Any setting that is not set is automatically inherited from the Elasticsearch output configuration, so if you have the Elasticsearch output configured such that it is pointing to your Elasticsearch monitoring cluster, you can simply uncomment the following line.

hosts.description: Array of hosts to connect to. Scheme and port can be left out and will be set to the default (http and 9200) In case you specify an additional path, the scheme is required: http://localhost:9200/path IPv6 addresses should always be defined as: https://[2001:db8::1]:9200

api_key.description: Authentication credentials - either API key or username/password.

parameters.description: Dictionary of HTTP parameters to pass within the URL with index operations.

headers.description: Custom HTTP headers to add to each request

proxy_url.description: X-My-Header: Contents of the header Proxy server url

max_retries.description: The number of times a particular Elasticsearch index operation is attempted. If the indexing operation doesn't succeed after this many retries, the events are dropped. The default is 3.

bulk_max_size.description: The maximum number of events to bulk in a single Elasticsearch bulk API index request. The default is 50.

backoff.init.description: The number of seconds to wait before trying to reconnect to Elasticsearch after a network error. After waiting backoff.init seconds, the Beat tries to reconnect. If the attempt fails, the backoff timer is increased exponentially up to backoff.max. After a successful connection, the backoff timer is reset. The default is 1s.

backoff.max.description: The maximum number of seconds to wait before attempting to connect to Elasticsearch after a network error. The default is 60s.

timeout.description: Configure HTTP request timeout before failing a request to Elasticsearch.

cloud.id.description: The `monitoring.cloud.id` setting overwrites the `monitoring.elasticsearch.hosts` setting. You can find the value for this setting in the Elastic Cloud web UI.

cloud.auth.description: The `monitoring.cloud.auth` setting overwrites the `monitoring.elasticsearch.username` and `monitoring.elasticsearch.password` settings. The format is `<user>:<pass>`.

enabled.description: Each beat can expose internal metrics through an HTTP endpoint. For security reasons the endpoint is disabled by default. This feature is currently experimental. Stats can be accessed through http://localhost:5066/stats. For pretty JSON output append ?pretty to the URL. Defines if the HTTP endpoint is enabled.

host.description: The HTTP endpoint will bind to this hostname, IP address, unix socket, or named pipe. When using IP addresses, it is recommended to only use localhost.

port.description: Port on which the HTTP endpoint will bind. Default is 5066.

named_pipe.user.description: Define which user should be owning the named pipe.

named_pipe.security_descriptor.description: Define which permissions should be applied to the named pipe, use the Security Descriptor Definition Language (SDDL) to define the permission. This option cannot be used with `http.user`.

pprof.enabled.description: Defines if the HTTP pprof endpoints are enabled. It is recommended that this is only enabled on localhost as these endpoints may leak data.

pprof.block_profile_rate.description: Controls the fraction of goroutine blocking events that are reported in the blocking profile.

pprof.mem_profile_rate.description: Controls the fraction of memory allocations that are recorded and reported in the memory profile.

pprof.mutex_profile_rate.description: Controls the fraction of mutex contention events that are reported in the mutex profile.

enabled.description: Enable or disable seccomp system call filtering on Linux. Default is enabled.
Set to true to enable instrumentation of filebeat.

environment.description: Environment in which filebeat is running on (eg: staging, production, etc.)

hosts.description: APM Server hosts to report instrumentation results to.

api_key.description: API Key for the APM Server(s). If api_key is set then secret_token will be ignored.

secret_token.description: Secret token for the APM Server(s).

profiling.description: Enable profiling of the server, recording profile samples as events. This feature is experimental.

enabled.description: Set to true to enable CPU profiling.
Set to true to enable heap profiling.

6_to_7.enabled.description: This allows to enable 6.7 migration aliases

moduleInput.description: Behind the scenes, each module starts a Filebeat input. Advanced users can add or override any input settings here.
moduleInput.markdownDescription:
**input configuration** ([documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/beats/filebeat/8.14/configuration-filebeat-options.html#filebeat-input-types))  
Behind the scenes, each module starts a Filebeat input. Advanced users can add or override any input settings here.

framing.description: Specify the framing used to split incoming events. Can be one of delimiter or rfc6587. delimiter uses the characters specified in line_delimiter to split the incoming events. rfc6587 supports octet counting and non-transparent framing as described in RFC6587. line_delimiter is used to split the events in non-transparent framing. The default is delimiter.

host.description: The host and UDP port to listen on for event streams.

timeout.description: The read and write timeout for socket operations.

enabled.description: Use the enabled option to enable and disable inputs. By default, enabled is set to true.

tags.description: A list of tags that Filebeat includes in the tags field of each published event. Tags make it easy to select specific events in Kibana or apply conditional filtering in Logstash. These tags will be appended to the list of tags specified in the general configuration.

fields.description: Optional fields that you can specify to add additional information to the output. For example, you might add fields that you can use for filtering log data. Fields can be scalar values, arrays, dictionaries, or any nested combination of these. By default, the fields that you specify here will be grouped under a fields sub-dictionary in the output document. To store the custom fields as top-level fields, set the fields_under_root option to true. If a duplicate field is declared in the general configuration, then its value will be overwritten by the value declared here.

fields_under_root.description: If this option is set to true, the custom fields are stored as top-level fields in the output document instead of being grouped under a fields sub-dictionary. If the custom field names conflict with other field names added by Filebeat, then the custom fields overwrite the other fields.

processors.description: A list of processors to apply to the input data.

pipeline.description: The Ingest Node pipeline ID to set for the events generated by this input. The pipeline ID can also be configured in the Elasticsearch output, but this option usually results in simpler configuration files. If the pipeline is configured both in the input and output, the option from the input is used.

keep_null.description: If this option is set to true, fields with null values will be published in the output document. By default, keep_null is set to false.

index.description:
If present, this formatted string overrides the index for events from this input (for elasticsearch outputs), or sets the raw_index field of the event’s metadata (for other outputs). This string can only refer to the agent name and version and the event timestamp; for access to dynamic fields, use output.elasticsearch.index or a processor.
Example value: "%{[agent.name]}-myindex-%{+yyyy.MM.dd}" might expand to "filebeat-myindex-2019.11.01".

publisher_pipeline.disable_host.description: By default, all events contain host.name. This option can be set to true to disable the addition of this field to all events. The default value is false.

cloud.description: Elastic Cloud authentication. These settings simplify using Filebeat with the Elastic Cloud.
cloud.markdownDescription:
**Elastic Cloud authentication** ([documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/beats/filebeat/8.14/configure-cloud-id.html))  
These settings simplify using Filebeat with the Elastic Cloud.

id.description: The cloud.id setting overwrites the `output.elasticsearch.hosts` and `setup.kibana.host` options. You can find the `cloud.id` in the Elastic Cloud web UI.

auth.description: The cloud.auth setting overwrites the `output.elasticsearch.username` and `output.elasticsearch.password` settings. The format is `<user>:<pass>`.

condition.description: describe condition that must be matched
condition.markdownDescription:
**condition** ([documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/beats/filebeat/8.14/defining-processors.html#conditions))  
describe condition that must be matched

equals.description:
With the equals condition, you can compare if a field has a certain value. The condition accepts only an integer or a string value.

For example, the following condition checks if the response code of the HTTP transaction is 200:

equals:
  http.response.code: 200

contains.description:
The contains condition checks if a value is part of a field. The field can be a string or an array of strings. The condition accepts only a string value.

For example, the following condition checks if an error is part of the transaction status:

contains:
  status: "Specific error"

regex.description:
The regexp condition checks the field against a regular expression. The condition accepts only strings.

For example, the following condition checks if the process name starts with foo:

regex:
  system.process.name: "^foo.*"

range.description:
The range condition checks if the field is in a certain range of values. The condition supports lt, lte, gt and gte. The condition accepts only integer or float values.

For example, the following condition checks for failed HTTP transactions by comparing the http.response.code field with 400:

range:
  http.response.code.gte: 400

network.description:
The network condition checks if the field is in a certain IP network range. Both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are supported. The network range may be specified using CIDR notation, like "192.0.2.0/24" or "2001:db8::/32", or by using named ranges (loopback, unicast, multicast, interface_local_multicast, link_local_unicast, link_local_multicast, private, public, unspecified).

The following condition returns true when destination.ip is within any of the given subnets:

network:
  destination.ip: ["192.168.1.0/24", loopback]

has_fields.description:
The has_fields condition checks if all the given fields exist in the event. The condition accepts a list of string values denoting the field names.

For example, the following condition checks if the http.response.code field is present in the event:

has_fields: ["http.response.code"]

or.description:
The or operator receives a list of conditions.

For example, to configure the condition http.response.code = 304 OR http.response.code = 404:

or:
  - equals:
      http.response.code: 304
  - equals:
      http.response.code: 404

and.description:
The and operator receives a list of conditions.

For example, to configure the condition http.response.code = 200 AND status = OK:

and:
  - equals:
      http.response.code: 200
  - equals:
      status: OK

not.description:
The not operator receives the condition to negate.

For example, to configure the condition NOT status = OK:

not:
  equals:
    status: OK

session_token.description: required when using temporary security credentials.

credential_profile_name.description: profile name in shared credentials file.

shared_credential_file.description: directory of the shared credentials file.

endpoint.description: URL of the entry point for an AWS web service. Most AWS services offer a regional endpoint that can be used to make requests. The general syntax of a regional endpoint is protocol://service-code.region-code.endpoint-code. Some services, such as IAM, do not support regions. The endpoints for these services do not include a region. In aws module, endpoint config is to set the endpoint-code part, such as amazonaws.com, amazonaws.com.cn, c2s.ic.gov, sc2s.sgov.gov.

request.transforms.description: List of transforms to apply to the request before each execution.

response.transforms.description: List of transforms to apply to the response once it is received.

response.pagination.description: List of transforms that will be applied to the response to every new page request. All the transforms from request.transform will be executed and then response.pagination will be added to modify the next request as needed. For subsequent responses, the usual response.transforms and response.split will be executed normally.

response.split.description: Split operation to apply to the response once it is received. A split can convert a map, array, or string into multiple events.

target.description: Defines the target field upon the split operation will be performed.

type.description: Defines the field type of the target. Allowed values: array, map, string. string requires the use of the delimiter options to specify what characters to split the string on. delimiter always behaves as if keep_parent is set to true. Default: array.

transforms.description:
A set of transforms can be defined. This list will be applied after response.transforms and after the object has been modified based on response.split[].keep_parent and response.split[].key_field.
Available transforms for response: [append, delete, set].
Can read state from: [.last_response.*, .first_event.*, .last_event.*, .cursor.*, .header.*, .url.*].
Can write state to: [body.*].

keep_parent.description: If set to true, the fields from the parent document (at the same level as target) will be kept. Otherwise a new document will be created using target as the root. Default: false.

delimiter.description: Required if using split type of string. This is the sub string used to split the string. For example if delimiter was "\n" and the string was "line 1\nline 2", then the split would result in "line 1" and "line 2".

key_field.description: Valid when used with type: map. When not empty, defines a new field where the original key value will be stored.

split.description: Nested split operation. Split operations can be nested at will. An event won’t be created until the deepest split operation is applied.

target.description: target defines the destination field where the value is stored.

value.description: value defines the value that will be stored and it is a value template.

default.description: default defines the fallback value whenever value is empty or the template parsing fails. Default templates do not have access to any state, only to functions.

target.description: target defines the destination field where the value is stored.

value.description: value defines the value that will be stored and it is a value template.

default.description: default defines the fallback value whenever value is empty or the template parsing fails. Default templates do not have access to any state, only to functions.

target.description: target defines the destination field to delete. If target is a list and not a single element, the complete list will be deleted.

supported_protocols.description: List of supported/valid TLS versions. By default all TLS versions from 1.1 up to 1.3 are enabled.

cipher_suites.description: Configure cipher suites to be used for SSL connections

curve_types.description: Configure curve types for ECDHE-based cipher suites

ca_sha256.description: Configure a pin that can be used to do extra validation of the verified certificate chain, this allow you to ensure that a specific certificate is used to validate the chain of trust. The pin is a base64 encoded string of the SHA-256 fingerprint.

certificate_authorities.description: List of root certificates for HTTPS server verifications

key_passphrase.description: Optional passphrase for decrypting the certificate key.

verification_mode.description: Controls the verification of certificates. Valid values are: * full, which verifies that the provided certificate is signed by a trusted authority (CA) and also verifies that the server's hostname (or IP address) matches the names identified within the certificate. * strict, which verifies that the provided certificate is signed by a trusted authority (CA) and also verifies that the server's hostname (or IP address) matches the names identified within the certificate. If the Subject Alternative Name is empty, it returns an error. * certificate, which verifies that the provided certificate is signed by a trusted authority (CA), but does not perform any hostname verification.  * none, which performs no verification of the server's certificate. This mode disables many of the security benefits of SSL/TLS and should only be used after very careful consideration. It is primarily intended as a temporary diagnostic mechanism when attempting to resolve TLS errors; its use in production environments is strongly discouraged. The default value is full.

renegotiation.description: Configure what types of renegotiation are supported. Valid options are never, once, and freely. Default is never.

client_authentication.description: The type of client authentication mode. When certificate_authorities is set, it defaults to required. Otherwise, it defaults to none.

multiline.description: Options that control how Filebeat deals with log messages that span multiple lines.
multiline.markdownDescription:
**multiline configuration** ([documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/beats/filebeat/8.14/multiline-examples.html))  
Options that control how Filebeat deals with log messages that span multiple lines.

type.description: Defines which aggregation method to use. The default is pattern. The other option is count which lets you aggregate constant number of lines.

pattern.description: Specifies the regular expression pattern to match. Depending on how you configure other multiline options, lines that match the specified regular expression are considered either continuations of a previous line or the start of a new multiline event. You can set the negate option to negate the pattern.

negate.description: Defines whether the pattern is negated. The default is false.

match.description: Specifies how Filebeat combines matching lines into an event. The settings are after or before. The behavior of these settings depends on what you specify for negate.

flush_pattern.description: Specifies a regular expression, in which the current multiline will be flushed from memory, ending the multiline-message.

max_lines.description: The maximum number of lines that can be combined into one event. If the multiline message contains more than max_lines, any additional lines are discarded. The default is 500.

timeout.description: After the specified timeout, Filebeat sends the multiline event even if no new pattern is found to start a new event. The default is 5s.

count_lines.description: The number of lines to aggregate into a single event.

skip_newline.description: When set, multiline events are concatenated without a line separator.

parsers.description: This option expects a list of parsers that the log line has to go through.
parsers.markdownDescription:
**Parsers configuration** ([documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/beats/filebeat/8.14/filebeat-input-filestream.html#_parsers))  
This option expects a list of parsers that the log line has to go through.

ndjson.description: These options make it possible for Filebeat to decode logs structured as JSON messages. Filebeat processes the logs line by line, so the JSON decoding only works if there is one JSON object per message.

target.description: The name of the new JSON object that should contain the parsed key value pairs. If you leave it empty, the new keys will go under root.

overwrite_keys.description: Values from the decoded JSON object overwrite the fields that Filebeat normally adds (type, source, offset, etc.) in case of conflicts. Disable it if you want to keep previously added values.

expand_keys.description: If this setting is enabled, Filebeat will recursively de-dot keys in the decoded JSON, and expand them into a hierarchical object structure. For example, {"a.b.c": 123} would be expanded into {"a":{"b":{"c":123}}}. This setting should be enabled when the input is produced by an ECS logger.

add_error_key.description: If this setting is enabled, Filebeat adds an 'error.message' and 'error.type: json' key in case of JSON unmarshalling errors or when a message_key is defined in the configuration but cannot be used.

message_key.description: An optional configuration setting that specifies a JSON key on which to apply the line filtering and multiline settings. If specified the key must be at the top level in the JSON object and the value associated with the key must be a string, otherwise no filtering or multiline aggregation will occur.

document_id.description: Option configuration setting that specifies the JSON key to set the document id. If configured, the field will be removed from the original JSON document and stored in @metadata._id

ignore_decoding_error.description: An optional configuration setting that specifies if JSON decoding errors should be logged or not. If set to true, errors will not be logged. The default is false.

container.description: Use the container parser to extract information from containers log files. It parses lines into common message lines, extracting timestamps too.

stream.description: Reads from the specified streams only: all, stdout or stderr. The default is all.

format.description: Use the given format when parsing logs: auto, docker or cri. The default is auto, it will automatically detect the format. To disable autodetection set any of the other options.

syslog.description: The syslog parser parses RFC 3146 and/or RFC 5424 formatted syslog messages.

format.description: TheThe syslog format to use, rfc3164, or rfc5424. To automatically detect the format from the log entries, set this option to auto. The default is auto.

timezone.description: IANA time zone name(e.g. America/New York) or a fixed time offset (e.g. +0200) to use when parsing syslog timestamps that do not contain a time zone. Local may be specified to use the machine’s local time zone. Defaults to Local.

log_errors.description: If this setting is enabled, the parser adds or appends to an error.message key with the parsing error that was encountered. Defaults to true.

include_message.description:
Use the include_message parser to filter messages in the parsers pipeline. Messages that match the provided pattern are passed to the next parser, the others are dropped.
You should use include_message instead of include_lines if you would like to control when the filtering happens. include_lines runs after the parsers, include_message runs in the parsers pipeline.

patterns.description: List of regexp patterns to match.

kerberos.markdownDescription:
**kerberos configuration** ([documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/beats/filebeat/8.14/configuration-kerberos.html))  
Configuration options for Kerberos authentication.

auth_type.description:
There are two options to authenticate with Kerberos KDC: password and keytab.
password expects the principal name and its password.
When choosing keytab, you have to specify a principal name and a path to a keytab. The keytab must contain the keys of the selected principal. Otherwise, authentication will fail.

config_path.description: You need to set the path to the krb5.conf, so Filebeat can find the Kerberos KDC to retrieve a ticket.

username.description: Name of the principal used to connect to the output.

password.description: If you configured password for auth_type, you have to provide a password for the selected principal.

keytab.description: If you configured keytab for auth_type, you have to provide the path to the keytab of the selected principal.

service_name.description: This option can only be configured for Kafka. It is the name of the Kafka service, usually kafka.

realm.description: Name of the realm where the output resides.

enable_krb5_fast.description: Enable Kerberos FAST authentication. This may conflict with some Active Directory installations. The default is false.

add_resource_metadata.description: Specify labels and annotations filters for the extra metadata coming from Node and Namespace. add_resource_metadata can be done for node or namespace. By default all labels will be included while annotations are not added by default. This settings are useful when labels' and annotations' storing requires special handling to avoid overloading the storage output. The enrichment of node or namespace metadata can be individually disabled by setting enabled: false.

enabled.description: The enrichment of node or namespace metadata can be individually disabled by setting enabled: false.

include_annotations.description: list of annotations to include in the event

include_labels.description: list of labels to include in the event

exclude_labels.description: list of labels to exclude from the event

processors.description: You can use processors to filter and enhance data before sending it to the configured output. To define a processor, you specify the processor name, an optional condition (with 'when' property), and a set of options
processors.markdownDescription:
**processors** ([documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/beats/filebeat/8.14/defining-processors.html#processors))  
You can use processors to filter and enhance data before sending it to the configured output.  
To define a processor, you specify the processor name, an optional condition (with 'when' property), and a set of options

add_cloud_metadata.description: The add_cloud_metadata processor enriches each event with instance metadata from the machine’s hosting provider. At startup it will query a list of hosting providers and cache the instance metadata.
add_cloud_metadata.markdownDescription:
**add_cloud_metadata** ([documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/beats/filebeat/8.14/add-cloud-metadata.html))  
The add_cloud_metadata processor enriches each event with instance metadata from the machine’s hosting provider. At startup it will query a list of hosting providers and cache the instance metadata.

timeout.description: specifies the maximum amount of time to wait for a successful response when detecting the hosting provider. The default timeout value is 3s.

providers.description:
The providers settings accepts a list of cloud provider names to be used. If providers is not configured, then all providers that do not access a remote endpoint are enabled by default.
Possible providers: alibaba, azure, digitalocean, aws, gcp, openstack, openstack-ssl, tencent

overwrite.description: When overwrite is true, add_cloud_metadata overwrites existing cloud.* fields (false by default).

move_fields.description: The move_fields processor moves event fields from one object into another. It can also rearrange fields or add a prefix to fields.
move_fields.markdownDescription:
**move_fields** ([documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/beats/filebeat/8.14/move-fields.html))  
The move_fields processor moves event fields from one object into another. It can also rearrange fields or add a prefix to fields.  
The processor extracts fields from `from`, then uses `fields` and `exclude` as filters to choose which fields to move into the `to` field.

from.markdownDescription: Which field you want extract. This field and any nested fields will be moved into to unless they are filtered out. If empty, indicates event root.

fields.markdownDescription: Which fields to extract from `from` and move to `to`. An empty list indicates all fields.

ignore_missing.markdownDescription: Ignore 'not found' errors when extracting fields. Default is false.

exclude.markdownDescription: Which fields to exclude from `from` and not move to `to`.

to.markdownDescription: These fields extract from `from` destination field prefix the `to` will base on fields root.

if.description: The if processor conditionally executes the processors that are defined in the then section. If the condition is not met, the processors in the else section are executed instead.
if.markdownDescription:
The if processor conditionally executes the processors that are defined in the `then` section.  
If the condition is not met, the processors in the `else` section are executed instead.

then.description: Processors to execute if the condition is met.
then.markdownDescription: Processors to execute if the condition is met.

else.description: Processors to execute if the condition is not met.
else.markdownDescription: Processors to execute if the condition is not met.

filebeat.autodiscover.description: When you run applications on containers, they become moving targets to the monitoring system. Autodiscover allows you to track them and adapt settings as changes happen. By defining configuration templates, the autodiscover subsystem can monitor services as they start running.
filebeat.autodiscover.markdownDescription:
**Autodiscover** ([documentation](https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/beats/filebeat/8.14/configuration-autodiscover.html))  
You run applications on containers, they become moving targets to the monitoring system. Autodiscover allows you to track them and adapt settings as changes happen. By defining configuration templates, the autodiscover subsystem can monitor services as they start running.

providers.description: Autodiscover providers work by watching for events on the system and translating those events into internal autodiscover events with a common format. When you configure the provider, you can optionally use fields from the autodiscover event to set conditions that, when met, launch specific configurations.

templates.description: You can define a set of configuration templates to be applied when the condition matches an event. Templates define a condition to match on autodiscover events, together with the list of configurations to launch when this condition happens.

config.description: Configuration contains a list of inputs and modules that are applied when template condition is matched.

host.description: Docker socket (UNIX or TCP socket). It uses unix:///var/run/docker.sock by default.

ssl.description: SSL configuration to use when connecting to the Docker socket.

cleanup_timeout.description: Specify the time of inactivity before stopping the running configuration for a container, 60s by default.

labels.dedot.description: Default to be false. If set to true, replace dots in labels with _.
Default to be true. If set to true, replace dots in labels with _.

annotations.dedot.description: Default to be true. If set to true, replace dots in labels with _.

node.description: Specify the node to scope filebeat to in case it cannot be accurately detected, as when running filebeat in host network mode.

namespace.description: Select the namespace from which to collect the metadata. If it is not set, the processor collects metadata from all namespaces. It is unset by default. The namespace configuration only applies to kubernetes resources that are namespace scoped.

cleanup_timeout.description: Specify the time of inactivity before stopping the running configuration for a container, 60s by default.

kube_config.description: Use given config file as configuration for Kubernetes client. If kube_config is not set, KUBECONFIG environment variable will be checked and if not present it will fall back to InCluster.

resource.description: Select the resource to do discovery on. Currently supported Kubernetes resources are pod, service and node. If not configured resource defaults to pod.

scope.description: Specify at what level autodiscover needs to be done at. scope can either take node or cluster as values. node scope allows discovery of resources in the specified node. cluster scope allows cluster wide discovery. Only pod and node resources can be discovered at node scope.

unique.description: Defaults to false. Marking an autodiscover provider as unique results into making the provider to enable the provided templates only when it will gain the leader lease. This setting can only be combined with cluster scope. When unique is enabled enabled, resource and add_resource_metadata settings are not taken into account.

leader_lease.description: Defaults to {beatname_lc}-cluster-leader. This will be name of the lock lease. One can monitor the status of the lease with kubectl describe lease beats-cluster-leader. Different Beats that refer to the same leader lease will be competitors in holding the lease and only one will be elected as leader each time.

include_annotations.description: list of annotations to include in the event

include_labels.description: list of labels to include in the event

exclude_labels.description: list of labels to exclude from the event

interfaces.description: network interfaces used for discovery probes

name.description: the name of the interface (e.g. br0), it can contain a wildcard as suffix to apply the same settings to multiple network interfaces of the same type (e.g. br*).

grace_period.description: time since the last reply to consider an instance stopped (defaults to 30s)

probe_timeout.description: max time to wait for responses since a probe is sent (defaults to 1s)
